140413779.review:
Portal, even nearly 2 decades later, holds as a charming, thought provoking, and immensely well designed puzzle game. Portal is very easy for players to pick up, and seamlessly trains you to be ready for the more "challenging" puzzles, that gain a sense of simplicity over time as the game teaches you the puzzle-solving skills needed to overcome them. Of course, the world, story, characters, and charm of the game is unmatched, but for the full experience, you need to discover that on your own.

10/10
A timeless classic.

130405556.review:
This is the classic game in the orange box that almost everyone has.  Story game play is easy and fun, but the achievement part is a different beast, at least to average player like me in games requires reaction.  

Most difficult achievement is the gold medal for challenge levels, especially the stage 18 least time.  I completed story mode and the other achievements a few years back and just couldn't hit the last stage least time after many tries.  Took a break since that. 

Recently completing the gauntlet speed run achievement in Titanfall 2 gave me confidence to come back and try this one again.  After hours of practice,  I finally made it and now I'm really happy.  Next long outstanding achievement will be the speedrun achievement for Braid, I guess. 

By the way, this game gave me a 3D motion sickness that I had never experienced in other games.  It was very common to lose sense of direction after passing through portals.  Probably not suitable for players prone to 3D motion sickness.

145255718.review:
[h1] ℙ𝕠𝕣𝕥𝕒𝕝 𝕚𝕤 𝕒𝕟 𝕆𝔾 𝕘𝕒𝕞𝕖 𝕗𝕣𝕠𝕞 𝕨𝕒𝕪 𝕓𝕒𝕔𝕜 𝕨𝕙𝕖𝕟 𝕍𝕒𝕝𝕧𝕖 𝕨𝕒𝕤 𝕤𝕥𝕚𝕝𝕝 𝕚𝕟 𝕥𝕙𝕖 𝕞𝕒𝕜𝕚𝕟𝕘! [/h1]

I'm just writing a review for this game because of the OCD; in a perfect world, literally everyone and their grandma know what Portal is... Let me start by just saying that I have an interpretation of this whole thing.

Maybe it's just me who feels this way, and maybe it's because they are all Valve games, but what if Portal takes places actually in the same world as Left 4 Dead (OR Half-Life, which is basically an Alien-induced apocalypse instead). That's right: in portal, you are this test subject, Chell, who is directed by a sentient robot AI into taking tests in Aperture Labs, to ultimately see how humans can deal with an apocalyptic scenario using the Portal guns.... That apocalyptic scenario being the same one in Left 4 Dead, a zombie apocalypse.. This theory of mine should be up to debate in Valve HQ, but I digress!

In Portal, you take the role of Chell, guided by the sentient robot AI Glados to complete a set of trials... using a portal gun, that allows traversal from point A to point B! You guessed it, it's a puzzle game divided into 19 levels, and a bunch of extra challenge maps for you to completely fry your brains while trying. After the 19 trials, Shell decides it's enough to leave the Aperture Labs for good and face the world above but Glados tries to stop her, saying that "We are not ready yet!" (half-confirming my theory). There is a whole actual mythos surrounding Glados, Aperture Science Labs and the Portal gun and surprisingly, a cake! The portal gun allows shall to maneuver through the levels while trying to avoid laser guns, and machine guns... and in the end, there's a major cliffhanger that sets the tone for the second game of the series.

In Portal, the puzzles are quite easy, it's the challenges that will have you rage, but they are all trial and error material, which means the more you play them, the more efficient you'd become at them. Portal is a [b]10/10[/b] puzzle game with very cryptic lore that would have you formulate theories inside of your mind, especially if you've played other Valve titles. It should be in a "Steam beginner's kit" or something, alongside games like Half-Life, Left 4 Dead, Payday and possibly Team Fortress... I can't shake the feeling that at least a couple of those games are directly related to Portal... Hummm, it remains to be seen I guess. Maybe Left 4 Dead 3 with the portal gun?? How cool would that be?

137583773.review:
What I can say about Portal is that this game is simply amazing. The combination of action, puzzles and humor is just perfect. The graphics and sound effects are impressive and help to really get lost in the game's world.

The portal mechanic, where you have to jump through portals to solve puzzles, challenges the brain in a way I haven't experienced in other games. It requires a lot of thinking, creative problem solving and spatial thinking, which makes the game constantly challenging and interesting.

And then there's the character "GLaDOS" who really is the perfect antagonist. Their scathing comments and sarcastic remarks often made me laugh and added to the overall atmosphere and character of the game.

I would recommend Portal to anyone looking for a unique and challenging gaming experience.

Highly recommended for anyone with a sense of direction, humor and a heart..

I have played more Portal 1 than any other person.  This is not something on my account from some seedy method, if you google "siblinghood portal" my speedrun.com page is at the top of the results and my high hour count is relatively known in the community.  This may change at some point, but at the time of writing I am the most qualified reviewer of portal possible, and I plan to take this responsibility as seriously as I can muster.

Portal was a marvel of technology at release.  Many design decisions had to be made due to technological limitations at the time.  It started development in 2005 and the task of programming to realize the vision for the game was a much more complex problem than perhaps any other game at the time.  Many corners had to be cut.  For one example, because the player's collision box is a rectangular prism that doesn't rotate, when walls don't run parallel to axes of the coordinate grid, they have different collision experiences with the player than you would intuitively expect.  You can see the impact of this in the level design.  The vast majority of surfaces in the game are parallel to two axes of the coordinate grids, making everything rectangular.  The portals themselves are also not eliptical on a mechanical level, they are rectangles, which you can feel for yourself once you've heard it.  Limitations in creation breed creative workarounds, and arbitrarily restricting the tools available to you is a technique you can see thoughout all artistic endeavors.  I believe this same concept applies in the case of Portal.  Its minimalist aesthetic and themes are enhanced by these circumstantial limitations, and don't, as one might initally assume, take away from its value today.

142399211.review:
[h1]Sweet cake[/h1]

Maybe I should have written a review a long time ago. Although it’s a fairly well-known game, well who hasn’t played this wonderful and sweet game. It be noticeable for its puzzle gameplay, portals, a good story, and soundtrack. Every time I play it, it's like getting a piece of cake after deciphering a puzzle; and the whole cake when I finish the game. I'll say a few brief things about [[u]insert the name of the game[/u]] while I finish my cake. I’d be keen on to underline three substantial elements of the game: the gameplay, the characters as the plot, and the soundtrack.

[h1]Welcome to Aperture Laboratories: a science of portals[/h1]

The simplicity and modesty of a game is usually the perfect recipe for a story like an impressive game. This is how it welcomes us with its minimalist style but with a whodunit enclosed within the Aperture complex.

The gameplay is pretty unpretentious: I have to try to succeed the test, go from A to B using cubes or spheres of energy that, placed on buttons, activate doors. Everything seems acceptable, a classic puzzle and escape room game. But what happens if there are hurdles that don’t permit me to take the cube? Hence an original intention of the game: the use of portals. In order not to address in detail, it’s enough to know that a device permits opening portals, A and B, with which I can make a path. Of course as long as the walls allot such a portal to be placed. I find the clues as signs, outlines or symbols indicate me what I can do and what I’ll hit upon there. In this way it guides a possible action for the player to do. It goes from the basic to the complex.

The game has fun logic that puts the brain to work. The enjoyable is to discover various ways to solve a puzzle to proceed in the plot. Furthermore, it has a stimulating physics simulation, in which through portals I can achieve a boost thanks to the acceleration (the momentum) caused by the fall. That way I can accomplish great distances or heights. Or just experience a free fall through portals, the terminal velocity, which makes it fun. I can only tell you that a test room has its limits, there’re assorted obstacles and the best each room escalates its difficulty. But always —something that distinguishes [i]Valve[/i]— it has its didactic pathway in which I learn little by little. It’s simple that can become multifarious ([i]vid. et.[/i] challenge mode).

[h1]The silent science between GLaDOS and Chell[/h1]

What I discerned, something that was to my penchant, the plot happens in a hermetic way. Everything ensues inside Aperture, whose staging combines minimalism (testing room) and industrial style (facility). As for the portals, optical illusions, perception and perspectives of space play a role.  Nevertheless, being secluded, although always fleetingly noticing a context that connects it, it tells the story of a lassie named Chell. Like any other day, she wakes up from her glass-walled room, the timer counting down, the music on the radio on, ready to carry out the test. A portal opens. Suddenly, something or someone alters the AI and she, unnoticed, tries to escape in routes that have already been explored by someone.

The story develops as I surpass the tests, at each step it becomes thought-provoking and well-planned plot. It’s intriguing, and it always tries to catch the player as if it didn't want us to leave. Every detail is meticulously pondering. I embodied into a test subject, though she’s always silent (comparable to Gordon Freeman). Instead, GLaDOS will be an opposite character, «someone» outgoing, sarcastic, sincere, and with a personality who’ll be talking the entire time on the walkthrough. It's those kind of villains with temperament you love and hate. Although sometimes that one intrigues being a voyeur almost all the instance in a world where there aren't many humans apparently. 

The narrative is also visual, where each detail tells a part of the story: sci-fi, enigmatic and airtight. Everything has personality, even the robot turrets that are charmingly lethal. What’s fun and, at the same time, petrifying is the supposed relationship that the antagonist links with the protagonist. It’ll clearly be noticeable in the song that closes the game. It's a perfect way to tie everything together: storytelling, gameplay, and soundtrack.

[h1]A cake for those who still alive[/h1]

One of the best pieces of music in video games is the [i]Still Alive[/i] song. It was written by Jonathan Coulton and performed by Ellen McLain. With an indie rock style, it reveals the sweet sincerity of the antagonist. He affirms that he hasn’t died but at the same time being an AI he expresses his feelings. It’s an emotional song, with a thought-provoking content with its humour and, at the same time, a frankness that is hard to forget.

Ellen's voice has been very sympathetic and friendly, she gives that sweet human tone to robotic part of the antagonist. Being her the voice that tests us, comments and expresses throughout the game. While on the radio it can be listen to in a samba version. It’s an excellent conclusion through music, where the voice of the antagonist and the melody of the song converge.

Although it isn’t the merely piece of music, it can be also perceived the dark ambient composition in many parts of the plot. It was composed by Kelly Bailey and Mike Morasky. The purpose of the soundtrack is to provide an atmosphere absorbed on a world dominated by computers. In this way I noticed its base of the dark ambient and giving off an enigmatic and synthetic atmosphere. For this, they merged ambient drone styles with minimalist piano and chip tune, with which it emphasizes such music was composed by a computer. Using arpeggios and mangled tones, prolonging towards downtempo, thus expresses odd, ethereal, and ominous sounds. It certainly contrasts an artificial music well done with an indie rock song that expresses the human side. It’s therefore an incredible, shocking and enjoyable soundtrack.

[h1]Cupcake[/h1]

Given its time, the game was thought to be durable due to the difficulty of each puzzle as well as the series of challenges. Although that will depend on the player. Without contemplating the diversity of possibilities to solve the puzzle, the game is short, but with a good plot and it’s quite re-playable. You can always discover new things along the way, which makes the game like a cupcake as a reward for playing it. It’s worth remembering the game as a classic in its style.

[h1]Recommendation: 10/10[/h1]

Feel free to visit my curator page for more charming games! c:
[/url][/quote]

A brilliant puzzle game that's still unique to this day, there's hardly much to say about it that hasn't been said already. You owe it to yourself to play it (and its sequel) if you tend to enjoy environmental puzzles. 
It's also worth noting that both Portal games go on sale for dirt cheap relatively frequently.

Talking about story, there is an interesting one to be found here even if it's left voluntarily vague for the most part. It feels Portal knows exactly when it should talk and when it should shut up so that you may take in its environments and ambience, letting Portal's peculiar atmosphere may seep in.

Portal 1 is what I'd consider short and sweet, it does leave you wanting more, but luckily with its sequel there's no shortage of more Portal to sink your teeth in. 
If you're someone that aims for 100% completion however, there are a couple of challenges that you can take on, one of which requires that you play the game again at least one more time looking for collectibles.

The other far more interesting challenge is a collection of six selected levels which individually test your skills in completing them with: least amount portals shot, fastest time, and least steps taken. The requirements for time and portals start to get a little unreasonable with chamber 15, the only challenge I found actually found to be actually unreasonable though is the "least steps taken" one, it's just not well thought out and I don't think it really fits the puzzle game nature of Portal at all unlike the other two.

Whether you want to just play the story and be done with it or try and 100% complete the game one thing's certain, Portal is a game that stood the test of time and that's worth playing even 16 years after its original release (at the time of writing).

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

127351344.review:
Set against the backdrop of the Half Life universe (which you wouldn't realize during play except for a few references or if you're a gigantic NERD), Portal has, since 2007, distinguished itself as an incredibly solid puzzle game. In 2023, however, it is difficult to find individual merits that its sequel, [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/620/Portal_2/]Portal 2[/url], doesn't do better. Portal with RTX came out at the latter end of 2022, and it's a cool gimmick, but doesn't change anything except appearances. Even then, not only are many gamers unable to try it anytime soon (lmao @ GPU prices and Steam hardware charts), but Portal 2 doesn't look comparatively bad without ray tracing capabilities. The only way it excels over its successor is in atmospheric horror elements. This is partly because it's a shorter game and these elements are much more concentrated, but also because the tone of its storytelling is less whimsical than Portal 2 and more reminiscent of Half Life. I will personally never forget the infamous "Rat Man" and those stujspid fjuKIcNg radios. Speaking of which, the achievements in this game - one of which involves taking radios that are scattered about the map into particular positions - are incredibly frustrating. I had some stupid input/control issues in all of the chamber 18 challenges where my camera would lock and then shake like a diabetic on low blood sugar when I tried to move it in the mid-air sections. Furthermore, the fuickNING sutpid least steps challenge category in general is the worst designed thing I have ever seen for a Source game. Honestly, this iteration of the fuhcciin Source engine holds it back so much, worst of all being that there's no proper borderless windowed mode.

All that being said, if you were to take this game in a vacuum, it is still a very good game; it's Still Alive, if you will :^). Figuring out how to gain enough momentum to make a particular jump, maneuvering balls of energy to power on switches, working against a timer to quickly place your portals, and moreover just solving the puzzles correctly will fill you with typical puzzle game joy. The game and the gameplay loop flow well, and are only interrupted by the usual Source engine idiosyncrasies or optional content. 

It's short and it's sweet, but I believe there are better confections to seek in the now-identically-priced sequel.

Portal, one of the best puzzle games that exists, in portal we can solve puzzles and little by little discover things that will make you realize that not everything you know is true.

[h1] Introduction [/h1]
[hr]
In Portal we are the protagonist Chell, we are forced to do tests, since we are forced by a robot called GLaDOS, to do the tests we have the "Portal Gun" (Aperture Science Handheld Portal Device2), with this weapon you can place portals to will of two colors, Blue and orange, these portals are placed depending on the button you press, if it is the left or right click. After doing several tests we will gradually realize that not everything we have been told is true and if you investigate well you will find out extra information that will help you understand everything that is happening.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
[hr]
The gameplay is very clean, there are no unnecessarily difficult levels (in the story mode), we will try different mechanics through the portals, carrying objects from one place to another, occupying the acceleration of the fall to reach a higher place and many other mechanics. As a player who completes it 100% having to do all the challenges, for all the time I invested in them I say that they are a real challenge, there are several modes, one where you have to spend the least amount of time, another in which which one you have to occupy the fewest number of portals and finally one where you have to occupy the fewest number of steps. In each challenge you have to think a lot about the strategy in order to have enough time to be able to get the best time, making you think a lot until you reach the strategy in which you can achieve your goal.

[h1] To Finish [/h1]
[hr]
This is a game that is truly 100% worth it, it is a game that will make you think, but without extreme difficulty, without a doubt a game that you need to play.

144292355.review:
Classic game. A bit short in playtime though and half of it  does feel like tutorial. Good story for the time, it seems a bit tamer now in the era of generative AI and LLMs. 

There is something to say about how we understand how technologies of today will scale and impact us in the future, something which I believe has been a trend in human history for a very long time. 

The subtle nod to stories based in reality often go overlooked and under-appreciated in the over-the-top spectacle of entertainment. The game is a very deliberate on-the-nose appreciation of that role in fictional media. But across the story-telling landscape we are full of lessons told but lessons not practiced. 

There is a lot more to get into and its not about seeking change in the world because one wants to be disruptive, but because we inherently believe in doing what is right and opposing that which is not and the hope that stems from that in what many can view as a forlorn world.

Guess I'll do the advanced chambers before uninstalling. Cheers.

142783484.review:
Ladies and gentlemen, step into the Aperture Science Enrichment Center, where portals are your best friends, and GLaDOS is your (mostly) benevolent overseer. Portal, developed by Valve, is a mind-bending puzzle game that has left players scratching their heads and laughing out loud since its release. So buckle up, because this review will take you on a journey through portals, puzzles, and plenty of witty humor.

Gameplay and Puzzles:
At its core, Portal is a game about thinking with portals – a concept that's more intriguing than watching a cat chase a laser pointer. Armed with a portal gun, you'll navigate through a series of test chambers, where the laws of physics bend like a contortionist in a circus. The puzzles start out simple, but soon enough, you'll be scratching your head like a confused monkey in a lab coat.

Each puzzle is a delightful mix of creative problem-solving and spatial awareness, challenging you to think outside the box – or, in this case, with portals. You'll feel like a scientific wizard, conjuring up portals to fling yourself across chasms and outsmart turrets like a stealthy ninja.

GLaDOS and Humor:
Ah, GLaDOS – the AI overlord with a penchant for dark humor and passive-aggressive compliments. Her witty remarks are as sharp as a diamond-edged portal, and her voice is as mesmerizing as a siren's song. Be prepared for her playful taunts and sarcastic quips, because she'll keep you company throughout your journey like an entertaining but slightly sinister tour guide.

The humor in Portal is a delightful surprise, bringing levity to the mind-bending puzzles. It's like finding a cupcake in a room filled with deadly lasers – a pleasant and unexpected treat. Whether it's the witty banter from GLaDOS or the hilarious observations found scribbled on walls, the game's humor is as delightful as a cake-loving companion cube.

Narrative and World-building:
For a puzzle game, Portal boasts a surprisingly compelling narrative. As you delve deeper into the test chambers, you'll uncover the mysteries behind Aperture Science and your place in this grand experiment. The world-building is as immersive as being caught in a time loop with Groundhog Day references.

Portal's story is concise, yet it leaves a lasting impact like a memorable haiku. You'll find yourself invested in unraveling the secrets of the facility, all while trying to avoid falling into bottomless pits like a cat avoiding water.

Graphics and Sound:
Portal's minimalist design is a stroke of genius, like a master painter using just a few brushstrokes to create a masterpiece. The stark, sterile environments of the Aperture Science Enrichment Center set the perfect backdrop for your mind-bending adventures.

The game's sound design is equally brilliant, with a captivating ambient soundtrack that immerses you in the eerie atmosphere of the facility. The sound effects, from the comforting hum of portal creation to the satisfying thunk of cubes hitting buttons, are as satisfying as solving a particularly tricky puzzle.

Short and Sweet:
One might argue that Portal's only flaw is its brevity. But like a perfectly crafted dessert, it's not about the quantity; it's about the quality. Portal may be short, but it leaves you wanting more like an insatiable craving for cake.

The game's length ensures that it never overstays its welcome, and the experience is as compact and polished as a portal gun freshly calibrated. You can easily complete the game in a single sitting, but its impact will linger in your mind like a thought-provoking riddle.

Conclusion:
In conclusion, Portal is a puzzle game that's as charming as a robot companion with a dry sense of humor. Its mind-bending puzzles, witty humor, and concise storytelling make it a true gem in the gaming world.

So, if you're ready to embark on a portal-hopping adventure and find out why the cake is always a lie, step into the world of Aperture Science. The challenges will twist your mind like a pretzel, but the laughs and satisfaction of solving each puzzle will make it all worth it.

Prepare to be immersed in a world where portals are your best tools and GLaDOS is your (mostly) friendly guide. Welcome to Portal – the game that proves that puzzle-solving can be both intellectually stimulating and hilariously entertaining. Now, grab your portal gun and get ready to think with portals!

147045408.review:
Portal Review

For all its heady delights, Portal is a short-lived feast and can be reasonably completed in as little as five hours. To help draw things out a bit, Valve has included six advanced chambers, all of which are existing test chambers tweaked to present a tougher challenge. You can also take on challenge maps and attempt to complete the test chambers with the least number of portals, the least steps, or in the least time. Ever since it was originally released more than six months ago, there has been ample time for the online community to produce a bevy of maps that, though varying in quality, are freely available for any test-chamber-hungry portaler to download. Its Orange Box roots mean that Portal also comes equipped with in-game achievements that can serve to extend its longevity. Nevertheless, the odds are that it'll be over a bit too quickly for your liking.

If portal technology is the meat of the game, then GLaDOS is the perfectly paired wine. The omnipresent voice that guides you through the test chambers, GLaDOS initially reveals a dry, almost unintentional sense of humor in the first few test chambers. As you progress, her humor begins to show signs of self-awareness, eventually blossoming into something too hilarious and too well-deployed to spoil here. Suffice it to say, it is one of the chief pleasures of Portal and features some of the best writing in video game history.

Short as it may be, Portal is a fantastic game that should be played by anyone interested in unique, well-crafted gameplay and a witty, whip-smart script. The stand-alone retail release comes with the same price point as the downloadable Steam release, which is about the cost of a night out at the movies. Portal may not last much longer than some feature films, but pound for pound it remains one of the best games on store shelves. This game is still alive!

146886486.review:
Portal is a singleplayer first-person puzzle game made by Valve back in 2007.

You go through several test chambers solving puzzles, usually trying to find a way to get a cube on to a switch so that you can open a door to the next area.

It's a really short game, but quite the experience.

I think everyone should play this game at least once, It's well worth your time and you're going to have a lot of fun playing it I can pretty much guarantee.

141380263.review:
Portal is an absolute classic gem of a Valve game, and it still holds up well in 2023 with graphics and gameplay.
The concept is amazing, having to use portals to complete puzzles where you must reach certain areas that you normally cant reach or using portals to help you with level objectives like avoiding sentries, reaching a cube, or activating a door. 
The story is not too long, consisting of 25 "levels" in total. However for 100% completionists, you will have to play the main story twice due to an achievement only being possible on a 2nd playthrough. There is also challenges and advanced versions of later levels to play as well.
The sound track is absolutely AMAZING and really fits the game well. You will want to listen to it outside of the game, its that good. Shoutout to the radio track.
Custom levels exist, however way harder to get working compared to Portal 2.
I absolutely recommend playing this one before the 2nd one, as it serves as a great introduction to mechanics and storyline.
This game can be purchased for a steal of a price in the Valve Complete Pack during sales.
Absolute amazing experience and a must play for anyone who is a fan of Valve or puzzle games.

Portal, developed by Valve Corporation, is a groundbreaking puzzle-platformer that revolutionized the gaming industry with its innovative mechanics and clever storytelling. Released as part of The Orange Box collection, Portal quickly became a cult classic, captivating players with its mind-bending puzzles, dark humor, and memorable antagonist. With its unique gameplay, immersive atmosphere, and captivating narrative, Portal remains a must-play title for puzzle enthusiasts and fans of thought-provoking storytelling.

Gameplay and Mechanics:
At the heart of Portal lies its ingenious gameplay mechanic: the portal gun. Players take control of Chell, a silent protagonist, equipped with a device that allows her to create portals on certain surfaces. These portals act as gateways, enabling Chell to navigate through complex test chambers, solve intricate puzzles, and overcome various obstacles.

The puzzles in Portal are brilliantly designed, progressively increasing in complexity as players advance through the game. Manipulating gravity, momentum, and environmental objects to solve puzzles feels satisfying and mind-bending. The mechanics offer a unique blend of physics-based gameplay and logic, challenging players to think outside the box and approach problems from different perspectives.

Narrative and Dark Humor:
Portal's narrative is an exceptional example of minimalist storytelling. Through a series of test chambers in the Aperture Science Enrichment Center, players uncover the dark secrets behind the facility and its enigmatic AI antagonist, GLaDOS. The dark humor and snarky remarks delivered by GLaDOS inject the game with a distinct personality, making for a memorable and often hilarious experience.

The progression of the story, the unraveling of the mystery, and the subtle hints scattered throughout the test chambers create an immersive and thought-provoking atmosphere. The finale of the game delivers a surprising twist that leaves players with a sense of awe and a desire for more.

Level Design and Atmosphere:
Portal's level design is a masterclass in simplicity and elegance. The sterile test chambers, with their clean lines and minimalist aesthetic, provide the perfect backdrop for the gameplay. Each chamber introduces new elements and mechanics, keeping players engaged and eager to discover what lies beyond the next portal.

The game's atmosphere is enhanced by the hauntingly atmospheric sound design, with ambient noises, robotic voices, and a subtle musical score that adds to the sense of isolation and mystery. The attention to detail in the environment and the meticulous design of each chamber contribute to the overall immersion and sense of discovery.

Conclusion:
Portal is a masterpiece of game design, combining innovative mechanics, captivating storytelling, and atmospheric level design into a unique and unforgettable experience. Its mind-bending puzzles, dark humor, and memorable antagonist have left an indelible mark on the gaming industry. Whether players are unraveling the secrets of the Aperture Science Enrichment Center or engaging in challenging puzzle-solving, Portal offers a thought-provoking adventure that stands the test of time. Prepare to embrace the mind-bending possibilities of the portal gun and dive into the extraordinary world of Portal.

139681030.review:
[h1]Holy![/h1]

The portal gun is the most exciting thing to happen to FPS games since the gravity gun, and it's no surprise to discover that Valve is agonising over whether to give it to Gordon Freeman. Its function is simple: bridging gaps. But, in doing so, it alters the way in which you approach an FPS environment so radically that it's hard to think past it. Give it to Gordon, and Half-Life will never be the same. Better to keep it in the family, but away from the action. That's what Portal does, and the results are interesting.

Waking in a small glass room at an unknown location, you're welcomed ("again") to the Aperture Science Enrichment Centre, a sequence of 19 scenarios designed to test your ability to use portals to bypass concrete walls, transport crates over impossible obstacles, slingshot yourself across chasms and overcome mischievous gun turrets. The first levels serve as a gentle introduction to the various concepts at work, and it's a good few minutes before you gain access to the weapon itself, and even longer before it's fully operational. Once it is, you can fire a blue portal at one surface and an orange portal at another, step through either and exit the other.

Levels demand a mixture of skills, all of which make use of portals in some way and your new tool when you acquire it. Some involve transporting crates to red switches in other areas of the test chamber; others, redirecting flying energy pellets to power up doors and platforms. The gun turrets, armoured on the sides and alarmingly powerful, represent a more dangerous obstacle, cutting you down if you stray into their sights for even a second, and need to be knocked over to disable them, or avoided altogether. Framing the gameplay are the portal placement restrictions - grey concrete floors, walls and ceilings can accept a portal, but reflective black sections, moving surfaces, doors, glass partitions and other world-objects cannot - and those springy metal rods tied to your calves, which allow you to fall over vast distances without incurring damage.

Most exciting are the sections that rely on momentum, which is conserved as you travel through portals. Place an entrance at ground level and an exit high up on a wall and step through the lower portal so that you're tumbling from a great height, and rather than simply land on the floor again you can reposition the entrance portal to catch you, which has the effect of throwing you out of the elevated portal a second time at terrific velocity. The implications ought to be obvious, and the puzzles that derive from this mechanic are some of the game's best and most spectacular, calling to mind the vehicular acrobatics of TrackMania.
Accompanying you on your journey and helping you to understand what's going on is the robotic voice of the AI that governs the test centre, GLaDOS - part instructor, part antagonist, total fruit-loop. While you learn, she keeps you amused, reminding you that any appearance of danger is "merely a device to enhance your testing experience", promising not to watch, then promising to stop lying about not watching you, and complimenting you on your intuition. "You remain resolute and resourceful in an atmosphere of extreme pessimism," she intones without emotion, before promising cake if you win.

If you've spent as much time analysing the original Portal trailer as we have, you might wish GLaDOS would stop jabbering and let you have your fun, but this would be unwise, as the education you receive is important and cleverly articulated. One of the game's great strengths, if not its greatest, is that concepts are introduced in such a way that players are entertained and informed without exception or confusion, guided by subtle design decisions that emphasise particular elements and concepts by constraining your actions without ever actually seeming to. If another Gordon, Brown, is reading, we'd like to nominate Valve to take charge of Britain's education system. The people there could stand to start thinking with portals.

Yet despite a remarkable economy of design, Valve gets more out of the portal gun than it ever did out of gravity. It may only be one weapon, with you for the majority of the game, but it's easier to think of your growing portal expertise as a substitute for your traditional FPS arsenal. In your head, each scenario has you scrolling a mental mousewheel of abilities and tricks. Would this work here? What about that? As you apply their logic to the scenarios playing out in front of you, they slot into increasingly elaborate combination, and new ideas present themselves intuitively.

Taken out of context, screenshots of vast rooms, full of networked infrared sentry beams, floating platforms, angled walls and flying energy pellets appear overwhelming; in the context of the game they are simply fascinating challenges that you are well equipped to overcome. It's rewarding, not frustrating, to sit and ponder one, partly because of that economy of design, partly because the pacing is so patiently considered, and partly because it always comes together with such delightful eloquence. And, of course, partly because GLaDOS is always there with something to say.

GLaDOS does more than simply guide you, however - she is the heart and soul of Portal's biggest surprise. Know simply that Valve harnesses its strengths in storytelling to drive your fascination with the Enrichment Centre - as wonderfully realised a location as anywhere in Half-Life - and with GlaDOS.

As the game reaches its apex, the scripted feel of the earlier levels is ousted in favour of something closer to a Half-Life episode. Its conclusion is funny, original and extremely memorable, as you dismantle the game's very personality and achieve a manner of revenge. Gabe Newell was right when he said it was Valve's best to date.

'Advanced' tours through the latter six test chamber scenarios with seemingly vital elements removed, or conditions skewed to enhance the difficulty. The Weighted Cube becomes a bouncy ball, while other solutions, dependent on the flinging concept, do away with charitable portal surfaces, forcing you to leverage every second of a pliable surface's exposure, laying down exits during feats of acrobatics with the precision of a traditional twitch-killer. One of the best advanced levels is the adaptation of a mid-game scenario built primarily around sentry guns, this time encasing them in indestructible cages, forcing you to build your strategy around evasion rather than confrontation for the second attempt. More of this, in the form of downloadable content, will be welcome.

Elsewhere, 'Challenge' mode imposes other conditions - using the fewest number of portals, the least possible number of steps (effectively the opposite of the least-portals goal), or achieving the solution in the shortest amount of time. More than simply space-fillers, the challenge levels help drive you toward new patterns of play, revisiting levels with a view to reduce them to the purest, simplest solution. You'll tear your hair out in places, but bending the rules of the already thoroughly bent portal gun rulebook is worth the aggravation.

More will undoubtedly follow, of course - as Gabe Newell remarks at the outset of the developer commentary, Valve feels it is only touching the surface of the portal mechanic's potential - and so we have that to look forward to, and the rest of The Orange Box to enjoy in the meantime. We've had potential before, though, with student game Narbacular Drop, Portal's predecessor, and this was meant to deliver on it. And so we're left with a curious contradiction: one of the most interesting and delightful things Valve's ever done, but also one of its least fulfilling. If only we had our own portal gun to bridge the gap to the first infusion of new content, perhaps we could forget it. Either that, or the next best thing - Companion Cube plush toys. It's surely only a matter of time.

I just played this for the first time in 2023. I always heard about it and how great it is, but never got around to playing it. I enjoyed this game and thought it was very creative. There should be more games like this out there. However, my only gripe is that it is much too short.

The whole time I was playing through the campaign, I thought it was just a lengthy tutorial to get me used to the mechanics of the game, and then the real fun/challenge would start. When I got to the final boss battle, I thought, "This must be the end of the first chapter or something." The credits started to roll, and I thought it was one of those "fake-outs" where the game makes you think it's ending but then it will still continue. But no, it actually ended. Although I did enjoy the innovation of the game, I felt it was much too easy and short. The bonus "advanced" maps were the only ones actually challenging for me, and I wish levels like those were implemented into a longer campaign.

I have come to understand that the reason this is a short game is because it was experimental for Valve at the time, and then due to the widespread positive reception, they went all in on Portal 2. So I am hoping that the sequel is much more satisfactory for me.

I'm currently getting back into playing games on my PC. I had a pretty small library on Steam and thought " Why not run through some classic Valve titles?". So that's what I'm doing. 

I haven't played anything related to Portal since or before I found a demo station set up at a Fry's Electronics when Portal 2 was released. So getting to have more than five minutes with this franchise was something that I felt was long overdue. Portal is THE PUZZLE GAME. Each chamber to a degree adds a new way to make you think and solve your current chamber. I was going pretty quick at the start solving the first couple of chambers quickly, and stopped to think on a few after that. However, I do feel like there was a difficulty spike that was a bit under prepped. Chamber 17-19 were a challenge. A welcome challenge, but one I was thrown off by. Especially, after running through most of the early ones. Now, this doesn't really make me like the game less. Just took me more time and had to think a bit more.

I also have seen a couple of people complain about the graphics, which dont really bother me. I know I'm playing a game released in 2007 and never did I stop to think a texture was too low res or muddy. Plus, if the graphics are an issue see if you can run Portal with RTX on your machine. From what I understand it is an amazing addition.

On the topic of the games length. It's short.

But, there are extra maps for you to try, and I can't wait to hop in those and check them out.

Overall if I were to give some sort of rating I would say this game is a solid 4 out of 5. It's got a lot of charm and character. I highly recommend giving it a go.

135069005.review: Portal is another one of Valve's masterpieces that was a unique and creative puzzle game back when it was released and still remains so although it's now dwarfed by its sequel. The base campaign, primarily comprised of 19 chambers, features mostly basic puzzles before you solve gradually more difficult puzzles and the true meat of the game in the final 7. The game features some haunting and mysterious gentle electronic music, alongside a couple of action tracks, before finishing the game off with one of the best credit songs in gaming. The game makes up for its primarily sterile and boring environment by adding some disturbing lore sections and filling you with intrigue about its haunting loneliness and how you got there, especially when you get to explore outside of the test chambers after the twist. But contrary to my description thus far, the game hardly takes itself that seriously because of the hilarious sarcastic dialogue from the game's only voiced character, the AI GLaDOS. The base campaign, taking a little under 3 hours, is too short to display the incredible possibilities for puzzles with the portal guns though, so the game also included more difficult versions of chambers 13-18 and three challenges to try and earn a gold ranking for each as well. There are also several other achievements that were enough to warrant another playthrough for me, especially after completing all of the challenges. I'm not typically an achievement hunter, but given the game's short length that gets shorter as you improve, it was worth it. Overall the entire game is a fantastic package with a quality campaign featuring fitting music, a comedic story, clever puzzles, and many side challenges that are worth completing for the satisfaction of spending more time in this game world even if some of them are frustrating (LOOKING AT YOU STEPS CHALLENGE). So there you have it, the game is an easy recommendation and a must play experience. 10/10

[b]TLDR;[/b] It's a must-play game that offers a satisfying gaming experience for fans of puzzle games and sci-fi stories alike.

Portal is an incredible game that will leave you thoroughly entertained and satisfied. From the moment you start playing, you'll be captivated by the innovative game mechanics, challenging puzzles, and witty humor that make this game a standout in the gaming world.

One of the things that makes Portal so great is its unique approach to puzzle-solving. The game challenges you to use a handheld portal device to navigate through various obstacles and reach your destination. The portal device allows you to create portals on walls, ceilings, and floors, enabling you to transport yourself and objects from one location to another. This innovative mechanic adds a whole new layer of strategy to the game and keeps you engaged and interested throughout.

In addition to its clever gameplay, Portal also features a fantastic story that will keep you invested from start to finish. The game is set in the Aperture Science Enrichment Center, where you play as a test subject who is forced to navigate through a series of increasingly difficult tests. The story is both entertaining and thought-provoking, and it's sure to leave you thinking long after you've completed the game.

Finally, Portal's visual and audio design are also worth mentioning. The game's clean, minimalist aesthetic is both striking and functional, and the sound design is perfectly suited to the game's sci-fi setting.

All in all, Portal is a must-play game that offers a unique and satisfying gaming experience. Whether you're a fan of puzzle games, sci-fi stories, or just great games in general, Portal is sure to impress.

134002673.review:
Portal is a puzzle game where you wake up from stasis and the next thing you hear is a robotic voice who will be the only other character you'll hear in the game.

The game is really fun and the puzzles are all very clever, though the game starts to truly shine in the later chambers, it is still pretty fun early on. While it's pretty fun, it doesn't last long (probably the biggest issue of the game too).
Once you're done, you could play another save from start for some achievements, do some advanced chambers and the challenges, but once you're done, the game lacks replayability. Even though its replay value isn't the highest, it's extremely good at worldbuilding.
The game has a sense of isolation that is prevalent everywhere. No other human being around, empty observation chambers, the very clinical and sterile look of the chambers all support this. There's also the sense that something's wrong, from the same robotic voice glitching out when she was going to say something important and putting you into harder and deadlier chambers the more you progress, almost as if she's not our friend. The game's artistic direction really helps to support these feelings, same for the soundtrack (probably even overshadowing the artistic direction since Portal's graphics are pretty aged, though it has aged really well).
The game has excellent design and difficulty overall. The game slowly adds onto the chambers by adding new test elements like cubes, buttons and energy pellets, teaching you about the preservation of momentum when you travel through the portals and adding hidden things like radios and sometimes rooms. The only time I'd say the difficulty and design gets ridiculous is in certain challenges like Least Steps Chamber 17 and Advanced Chamber 15, but these are extra content so I can't really call the overall difficulty and design bad.

Overall, Portal is a timeless masterpiece with great puzzles and a superb environment centered about the sense of isolation and the sense of something being wrong, supported by its clinical looking artistic direction and mysterious soundtrack. The only handicaps of the original Portal are the shortness of the main campaign, the lack of replayability afterwards and some of the extra chambers being kinda unfair, though these are still really overshadowed by Portal's positives. I'd say it's a 95/100.

Que no se ha dicho ya acerca del Portal.
Excelente juego de plataformas, con mecánicas tan simples pero entretenidas. Y con una gran sorpresa de fondo.
Desde un inicio se nos introduce las mecanicas básicas del juego, pero también, y muy acompañado de este, la historia del juego que va ocurriendo detrás y que le da un gran valor final.
Esto no va simplemente de resolver pruebas (al menos no en su totalidad). Si bien nos invita a pensar sobre como resolver estas 'cámaras' (hasta terminar buscando la solución en youtube), esto va muy acompañado de un por qué ocurren ciertas cosas o un por qué estan ciertos elementos presentes dentro de cada nivel (digase la radio, el cubo, etc). Dando una gran importancia sobre la trama en la medida que se nos va explicando el mundo detras de Portal.
Pasada la mitad del juego, la cual consiste en una serie de camaras sin un mayor propósito aparente, llegamos a la parte en donde GLaDOS se desase de la protagonista. O al menos ese era su plan. Ya desde este punto que el juego pasa de ser un simple rompecabezas, a ser un ESCAPA! Tomando la trama como el papel principal en el juego.
Me encanta como fueron capaces de convertir a GLaDOS, en un personaje totalmente memorable gracias a su humor cruel y sarcástico. Que sería de Portal sin sus comentarios pasivo-agresivo.

[h1] Portal[/h1]

 Portal, to me, is an unusual game, instead of any shooter, Valve decided to make their own puzzle game, and Portal ends up coming out. Compared to the second part of the series, this game looks like a demo for the second part. Seriously, this game takes at most 3 hours to get through. At least I got through it in an hour and a half. What or serious levels in this game, I did not observe, all passed in the same breath, without any hesitations.

[h1] The storyline. [/h1]

Spoiler ----

[spoiler] The game's protagonist, Chell, wakes up in the Aperture Science Development Center in the recreation chamber. GLEDOS greets Chell and suggests that we begin the test, which we do, since as such we have no choice. And we take the tests of GLEDOS in stages until we kill her. [/spoiler]

 From the outside, the plot is weak, but it also manages to be mysterious. It's all because of the details in the game itself. The developer reveals the lore of Portal, through the details in the tests. By the way, here's an interesting fact, the Portal action takes place in the same universe as Half-Life.

[h1] What to date? [/h1]

 Here I do not know what to answer, after passing the game for platinum, I have mixed feelings. On the one hand the game is cool, I would say - cool. On the other hand, it's very short, and such a feeling, as if cut everything. In general, only you can answer this question, I am powerless here.

129225166.review:
There is a reason that the phrase "thinking with portals" became such a mainstay among puzzles and games of all kinds.  True to the original goal of the game, the way a player perceives challenges and obstacles in the game is very unique and in my experience is surpassed only by Portal 2 (go figure).

The primary goal of the game is to clear multiple test chambers that involve the use of the Aperture Science Handheld Portal Device (portal gun).  By placing portals in strategic locations, the player can navigate these chambers with ease while screwing over classical physics in the process.  Combined with multiple objects to interact with the environment, the atmosphere of the game is fantastic.  When coupled with the impressive gameplay mechanics of the game, all the elements come together and mesh into a final product that just "feels" right, especially after figuring out a particularly tricky puzzle.

The story of the game on its own is relatively minimal, but what is there is masterfully executed, and was something completely different for the time.  Character interaction is limited to only one other primary entity, and conversations are completely one-sided.  This might seem like a bad thing at first, but because of the care given to the scenario by the writers combined with fantastic wit and timing again provides a truly unique experience.

The game is short, and for particularly savvy puzzle aficionados, the game can be finished in just a few hours.  This might be a deal breaker for some, but if you can get the game on sale for under a dollar, it is still absolutely worth it to experience the game at least once.  The main game isn't the only thing you can do, however.  There are also included advanced maps that modify some maps of the original game that really push your problem solving to the limit and are massively enjoyable.  Also available are the challenge maps that test your ability in completing levels from the game that have been layered with extra goal-oriented tasks such as using the least amount of portals, taking the least steps, and how quickly you can reach the end of a level.

The missions involving steps and least time were not my cup of tea and I immediately knew they were beyond my mental capacity, but the least portals challenge I found to be extremely rewarding, so there is something on offer for everyone here.

Overall, Portal is a fantastic game in almost every department, and it is a great example of why video games are wholly unique, as the game does things that are not possible in almost any other medium.  The game was ground-breaking when it first came out, and if you still haven't experienced the game, I highly recommend it.  In my opinion, the game is absolutely worth it at full price, but the game goes on sale very often, so you shouldn't have to wait long to pick it up easily.

128922591.review:
What more is there to say about Portal that hasn't been said a million times already? Portal is an unforgettable experience that everyone deserves to hold in their memory banks.

The beautifully simplistic story of a silent protagonist completing puzzles while armed with only a portal launching gun, guided by her iconic snarky robot guide, is delivered in a continuous stream of charisma that is stuffed with character. Humorous moments seamlessly blend into philosophical themes in a way that will make you laugh, and then leave you thinking about what role Aperture Science represents in reality.

Portal's game play is also simple: your portal gun shoots two portals, one blue one orange. What goes in one comes out the other and vice versa. The game does an excellent job of starting out very easy, and then slowly introducing elements that add complexity at a comfortable pace. The puzzles will eventually require you to think carefully and use everything you've learned to figure out the way forward, but it never feels frustrating, or like a chore.

You can blast through Portal in a day or two, so it's perfect if you don't want to commit to something that will require a large time investment. There's a few advanced puzzles to unlock after completion, as well as a healthy supply of community mod levels, so your portal adventures can continue after the credits roll if you choose. 

So what are you waiting for.  Go get your cake, you've earned it.

124668736.review:
After finally giving one of the most popular games from Valve a chance I can definitely see what has grabbed the attention of its players way back then.

Coming off as a first person puzzle game with the main mechanic being the ability to manage the portal physics, at the start it might feel trippy with the sudden camera changes that only get more intricate as the levels do more in a challenging way. It’s not as bad as it sounds though since it can be beaten in a couple of hours, leaving the additional maps and specific challenges to fill hours of revisits as well as achievements for exploration. This is all further enhanced by the inclusion of GLaDOS as a constant monitoring robot character who checks on our status while providing very memorable lines and contributing in a major way in its conclusion.

Not everything is dandy though as in my experience the grabbing object mechanic can result in overshimmering on some occasions. Not only that but there are a couple of platform hitboxes that don’t line up correctly during jumps, leading to unintentional deaths. All of this can become particularly annoying during some of the toughest sections that require some more precision than usual, not to mention the time trials. A final nitpick I have with the latter is the lack of a restart button to replace the reloading of a level upon a retry considering how hard they can be.

Nevertheless, I had quite the logically challenging experience and can’t wait to try it out again with RTX.

139196091.review:
Gameplay:
At its core, Portal is a first-person puzzle game that challenges players to navigate through a series of test chambers using the Aperture Science Handheld Portal Device, commonly known as the "portal gun." This device allows players to create linked portals on flat surfaces, creating a mind-bending environment where the laws of physics are defied.

The puzzles in Portal are brilliantly designed, requiring players to think creatively and use the portal gun strategically to solve them. The gradual increase in complexity keeps players engaged and motivated throughout the game. The satisfaction of successfully maneuvering through a challenging puzzle and the "aha" moments that come with discovering new solutions are incredibly rewarding.

Narrative:
While many puzzle games prioritize gameplay over story, Portal masterfully combines both elements to create a captivating experience. The game's narrative unfolds through the interactions between the player and an AI named GLaDOS, who guides and taunts the player throughout their journey. GLaDOS's sarcastic remarks and dark humor inject personality into the game, making it an unforgettable experience.

The story of Portal gradually reveals the unsettling truths behind the Aperture Science laboratories, immersing players in a mysterious and thought-provoking atmosphere. The narrative twists and turns, culminating in a memorable climax that will leave players pondering long after the game is over.

Presentation:
Portal's minimalist aesthetic perfectly complements its gameplay and narrative. The sterile test chambers, the vivid orange and blue portals, and the clean, futuristic design of the environment create a distinct visual style that remains iconic to this day. The game's sound design, including GLaDOS's voice acting and the atmospheric music, further enhance the immersion and add to the game's eerie atmosphere.

Replayability:
While Portal's main story can be completed in a few hours, its replayability lies in the joy of solving puzzles in new and creative ways. Players can strive for faster completion times, attempt to find hidden areas, or challenge themselves with advanced maps created by the game's dedicated community. Additionally, the inclusion of the "challenge mode" adds an extra layer of difficulty for those seeking an even greater puzzle-solving experience.

Conclusion:
Portal is an absolute masterpiece that has left an indelible mark on the gaming industry. Its innovative gameplay mechanics, intelligent puzzle design, and memorable narrative make it a must-play for any gaming enthusiast. Whether you're a fan of puzzle games or simply appreciate a well-crafted experience, Portal will captivate you from start to finish. Step into the Aperture Science laboratories and prepare to have your mind twisted and entertained in ways you never thought possible.

137092553.review:
So, this is probably one of the greatest puzzle games I have ever played. The reason being, despite having a fondness for them, with most puzzle games I eventually give up and look up a walkthrough. However, in this case, I didn't. I did all the puzzles by myself without relying on any walkthrough because the game is just that good at teaching you its mechanics that you know all the rules and are able to guess your surroundings and their possible solutions all on their own. There are plenty of visual hints to help you through (for example, in one of the room I needed to portal a energy ball from one room to another, and they were connected in such a way accompanied by the black circular marks on the walls where the energy ball hit, that after three to four minutes of exploring, I was able to guess what I needed to do). 
Another amazing part about this game is the humor. Oh lord the sarcastic british dry humor coming from GlaDOs's mouth is the thing I live for. The level design and structure is just brilliantly amazing, and each even when a level looked at first as confusing as a D-Angelo painting, I was able to guess where i needed to go and what i needed to do.
Like I felt like a genius after every solution, and it was in a way I never felt before. A game needs to be geniusely designed to make a player feel genius upon solving them, and this game not only accomplished that, but set a new standard. 
I am thankful that unlike some companies like Nintendo or 2K, valve at the very least have not only supported their modders but actively given them jobs in an industry where getting a job is tough as nails. Reminder, this game and TF2 are made by people who were both valve fans and just indie devs/modders trying to get by, and seeing these talented people make such talented game given an oppurtunity by another talented team is something I hope could be a standard for this industry. Because this game stands as not only a masterpiece in valve's history, but a masterpiece in gaming in general. Even if it is 2-3 hours long, those 2-3 hours are a million times better than 20-40 hours of some game. They are more genuine, fun, creative, and keeps you wanting more.
I will play Portal 2 when I am finished with a few other games, but this was genuinely amazing. 
Now...let's hope valve can count to three someday.

134783314.review:
My main run through was 2 hours. The game doesn't really start until you receive both Blue and Orange parts of the Aperture Science Handheld Portal Device, the pOrTaL gUn, but once you have it, it goes from fun to [i]good[/i]. Aside from the main content, this game features tons of bonus modes based on 6 of the base game's chambers. The first set is Challenge mode: there's a Time Attack, Minimum Steps, and Minimum Portals challenge that sets progressively harder goals as you get better scores. There's also Advanced Chambers, which directly modifies the same six levels to make them more difficult without using the Challenge Mode aspects.
     While it might seem like a draw-back that these levels get recycled, you get to see all the little details that have been put into each one, which helps you in completing the extra modes. If it weren't for the knowledge I had acquired of the general layout, these extra modes would have been a lot less enjoyable.
     I normally don't like voice acting in video games, and was disappointed when I found no option to turn off dialogue. I'm glad that I wasn't allowed to do that, because the voice acting is stellar. I still dislike voice acting, but this game is a pleasant exception.
     If you are like me but can't get over the voices or audio, the built-in subtitles are great. Even when I had audio on, I used the subtitles so I'd have a better idea of when turrets could see me or not.
     While I have played several games that are longer, this is one of those games that doesn't skip a beat in entertainment. Both ambitious and excellently designed, I'd say you might as well get it since it's often on sale for a dollar :)

Probably one of the best games I have ever played, despite being quite short and requiring only a few hours (5 for me) to complete. Would recommend to anybody, especially if they want a quick and fun puzzle game. 

While Portal is a 3d platforming and puzzle game, its unique mechanic of portals and great story help elevate it above the average titles in the genre. The story is quite simple, but effective. and has a lot of twists and jokes involved. First missions were quite easy, but the later ones were a bit more challenging. However, they were never so difficult I couldn't figure out the solution myself soon, and I got the gist of how portals worked quite soon. Actually, I might preferred the puzzles to be even a bit harder and more complicated.

The game could have been longer, but on the other hand, it is better to offer less content with more quality, and leave players wanting for more, rather than to artificially extend gametime by copy-pasting quests and locations.

However, the bonus levels and challenges can be a nightmare to achieve, so they are difficult

130066084.review:
[h1]Introduction:[/h1]
Portal is a first-person puzzle-platform game developed by Valve Corporation and released in 2007. As a fan of puzzle games, I was excited to try out Portal and see what all the hype was about.

[h1]Gameplay:[/h1]
The gameplay in Portal involves using a portal gun to create portals and navigate through a series of increasingly challenging test chambers. The controls were smooth and easy to use, and the puzzles were well-designed and satisfying to solve. However, one issue I had was that there were a few times when I encountered bugs that prevented me from completing a chamber, requiring me to restart.

[h1]Story:[/h1]
The story in Portal follows the player character, Chell, as they are subjected to a series of tests by the malevolent artificial intelligence GLaDOS. The story is told through the use of audio recordings and the environment, and it does a great job of building tension and mystery. However, I felt that the story was a bit too short and could have been fleshed out more.

[h1]Graphics and Sound:[/h1]
The graphics in Portal are simple but effective, with a clean and minimalist aesthetic that fits the game's setting of a laboratory. The sound design is also excellent, with the music adding to the atmosphere and the voice acting for GLaDOS being particularly standout.

[h1]Replay Value:[/h1]
While there are some unlockables and achievements to encourage replay, the main campaign of Portal is relatively short, with a first-time player like myself completing it in a little over 2 hours. This was my main criticism of the game, as I would have liked to see more content.

[h1]Conclusion:[/h1]
Overall, I enjoyed my time with Portal and thought it was a well-made puzzle game with a unique premise and great sound design. However, I felt that the short length and occasional bugs detracted from the experience. While I would still recommend it to fans of puzzle games, those looking for a longer experience may want to look elsewhere.

133788766.review:
Nowadays, Portal is just an appetizer before the grand meal that is Portal 2. Really, this game isn't worth picking up if you're expecting all the polish and fun of the second game. That being said though, I love this game. It's, of course, what set the making of the next game into motion and will forever remain a Valve time capsule and classic! 

The game is short but sweet, the puzzles never really get too difficult and i was able to solve many of them on my first try. The story, despite not being as put in the forefront as the second game, is great. GladOS provides many funny quips and the game really makes sure to try and get you attached to her even if she does brush off any possible danger to your life. I do recommend getting this game in particular when it's on one of its many sales, though, as i feel it isn't really worth the OG price tag for such a short length.

Portal is a fun little time if you want to twist your brain a bit while also getting massive headaches from all the portal radiation!!!

133786926.review:
A phenomenal game from start to finish. Many people wonder about portals as a kid, after seeing them in cartoons and movies. This game manages to perfectly implement how it would be to interact with portals. The story line is quite interesting and unique. The clean and tidy science labs, to the grimy and dark backrooms, they all fit in very well. Some graffiti and subtle warnings here and there, create an environment which keeps you hooked. The story also does a nice job of showing how a robot dominated world might look like. There are alot of puzzles to solve, in the main story and then the advanced chambers. While it's time consuming to solve them all by yourself, it's certainly worth it. And game walkthroughs/guides are always on the web, if you're stuck for too long...  

I had to deal with nausea in several chambers, where you have to portal around too quickly and gravity kept changing sides. Increasing FOV settings to 110 (max) helped me quite a bit, although this preference will change from person to person.

Absolutely recommended for teenagers and adults! Having a basic understanding of physics definitely helps to clear the game, which children may lack  xD 

[b]Personal rating[/b]: 10/10. 
I now want a cake, after finishing main story  :D
Go to Portal 2, after you feel like you've finished this game.

123594364.review:
[spoiler]The Cake is a lie[/spoiler]
Portal Chocolate Raspberry Cake Recipe

The cake does take a bit of time and a number of steps to create, but the end result is a beautiful and tasty cake you will be proud to serve to Portal game fans and those that have never heard of the game. If you like chocolate, you are going to love this cake. The hardest step is getting all those chocolate jimmies to stick to the cake, but it is easier than you think and just takes a soft touch to patting them into the frosting all around the cake. Be sure to put parchment under the cake before frosting to make it easier to clean up once decorating is complete.

Ingredients
Chocolate Cake
Devils Food Chocolate Cake Mix
Ingredients to make the cake according to the box
Raspberry Filling
1 1/2 cups frozen raspberries
1 Tbsp. cornstarch
2 tsp. lemon juice
1/4 cup sugar
Chocolate Buttercream Frosting
8 oz. semi-sweet chocolate chips
6 cups confectioners' sugar
16 Tbsp. (2 sticks) butter
6 Tbsp. milk, plus more, if needed
2 tsp. vanilla extract
¼ tsp. salt
Decorations
8 oz. tub Chocolate Jimmies
9 fresh raspberries
2 Tbsp. red currant jelly
1 can of whipping cream or small batch vanilla buttercream frosting (frosting holds up better)
1 white candle
Instructions
Chocolate Cake
Make the cake in two 9-inch layers
Raspberry Filling
Combine the frozen raspberries, cornstarch, lemon juice and sugar in a medium sauce pan over medium high heat, stirring occasionally till boiling.
Decrease the heat to medium and stir constantly until everything is dissolved and liquid.
You will see that the raspberries break down completely. Once the mixture has changed color to a deep dark red, remove from the heat and let it cool completely.
Chocolate Buttercream Frosting
Have all the ingredients at room temperature.
Put the chocolate in the top pan of a double boiler set over but not touching simmering water in the bottom pan. Stir until the chocolate is melted and smooth. Let cool to room temperature.
In the bowl of an electric mixer fitted with the flat beater, combine the confectioners' sugar, butter, the 6 Tbs. milk, the vanilla and salt andbeat on low speed until combined, about 1 minute. Stop the mixer and scrape down the sides of the bowl. Increase the speed to medium and beat for 2 minutes, then reduce the speed to low. Add the chocolate and beat until combined, then increase the speed to medium and beat for 1 minute more.
If the frosting is dry, add more milk, 1 tsp. at a time, until it is creamy but still holds peaks.
Assembling the Cake
Prepare the cake as directed on the box in two 9-inch pans. Cool completely.
Prepare the filling while the cake is baking and cool completely.
Prepare the frosting when ready to assemble the cake.
Melt red currant jelly in microwave for 20 seconds. Dip fresh raspberries completely and then put them into the fridge to set up.
Place bottom cake layer on the serving plate. Pipe a ring of frosting around the outside edge. This is to keep the filling in the center of the cake.
Fill the cake with the Raspberry filling and spread until it is level.
Place the top layer of cake over the bottom layer. Frost the entire cake.
Using your hands, press the chocolate jimmies into the frosting all around the cake and on top.
Using a decorators bag, pipe eight dollops of whipped cream or vanilla buttercream frosting (frosting holds up better).
Place one glazed raspberry onto each of the dollops.
When ready to serve, add one white candle to the center of the cake.

139792590.review: Portal is an experience from 2007 showing that not all first-person games have to be violent. Portal takes the first-person genre and combines it with the puzzle genre, creating a realistic yet entertaining gameplay journey. What makes Portal such a great game though is that it's easy to pick up and play for anyone regardless of age or skill, whereas most puzzle games are designed for experienced players who are familiar with the genre and are already proficient towards solving its challenges. Portal holds your hand throughout the whole game and still makes you feel competent for being able to solve it on your own. Portal doesn't have many mechanics, but it actually benefits the game more than it doesn't. For one thing, the mechanics are quality over quantity, and second, towards the end of the game, once you learn all of the mechanics, the game gives you puzzles where all of the necessary aspects that you have learned are put together into one big reward: A giant puzzle that, with your skills, makes the level beatable to you after you know exactly what needs to be done; you have everything you need to succeed. Not only does Portal, excel in showing that not all first-person games have to be running and gunning a bunch of enemies in a tightly-packed hallway, but it also shows that the setting of a game doesn't always have to rely on visuals. While the idea of being in a sterile environment filled with white-painted panels sounds boring, it fits the atmosphere perfectly of being in a testing environment, treated like an experiment or a lab rat. That, accompanied with the atmospheric droning music helps aid the game into achieving a very cold and almost lifeless tone. It gives off a feeling of anxiousness and dread to the player, putting them in that mood of fear one might feel when you know something big is coming. Portal strives with its gameplay, puzzle elements, overall mechanics, feeling, tone, and its pacing. Portal is a revolutionary game that I would recommend to everyone. Whether you are into puzzle games, want a first-person shooter with a twist, or just want to try something new, this is the game for you. 23487576.review:
[h1]AT A GLANCE[/h1]
(Full review follows below)

[list]
[*] [b]Game Name:[/b] Portal 
[*] [b]Original Release:[/b] 2007
[*] [b]Genre Tags:[/b] Innovative; Puzzle; Sci-Fi; Action; Funny
[*] [b]My Overall Grade:[/b] A+
[*] [b]Estimated Playtime (Campaign):[/b] 2-3 hours
[*] [b]Multiplayer Aspect:[/b] None
[*] [b]Recommended To:[/b] Established fans of the genre; Those intrigued by the genre; Novelty seekers; Casual gamers 
[/list]	

[h1]REVIEW[/h1]
[b]Portal[/b] is an amazing experience. In terms of video games: it is the very definition of short & sweet. There are many people out there overly concerned with the length of games, and I believe [b]Portal[/b] is an excellent example of why one shouldn’t immediately scoff at a short game due to prejudices. Sometimes 3 hours of perfection is better than 20 hours of mediocrity. Sit down, immerse yourself, and just play through the game in one sitting as you would if watching a movie. It is worth it.

I say this because I believe this is a game best enjoyed in one sitting. There are no lulls or down points, and every second of the game is riveting and purposeful. The whole experience is so genuinely entertaining and the pacing is so perfectly on point that I think it is designed to be played like this. In this way, I see the length of the game as a strength and not a weakness… but maybe I’m just crazy.

But what is it that makes the game so genuinely entertaining in the first place? Everything… and then some. The concept is innovative, the puzzles are intuitive and interesting, the atmosphere is captivating, and the dialogue is hilarious and flawless. And when all of these facets come together in the finished product, the whole becomes greater than the sum of its parts. And a game is created that transcends opinions: it is undeniably great.

Honestly, I respect everyone’s right to their own taste in video games; but if you don’t enjoy [b]Portal[/b], I would dutifully suggest you consider finding a new hobby. I would find it very hard to understand how anyone could possibly not enjoy this game if they consider themselves a “gamer.”

If you haven’t yet had the luxury of experiencing [b]Portal[/b], then I envy you. Stop thinking about it and just go for it.
